Harley then proceeded to report on the current state of each of the four
areas of the Lowell project he was supervising.
OUR AMERICAN HERITAGE: There are now four shows on tape. Claude Rains
appears on all of them. All were written by Wishengrad, and these are all
Wishengrad is going to do for the present. He may do the final one in the
series. Geiger, who has already written one of the USSR programs, is going
to work immediately on the next Jefferson script. Rains is currently in
London for a picture and will return about May 19. One of the big questions
for the committee is whether we should wait for him. It looks as though it
will be possible to have all the scripts ready for him to do two or three a
week when he returns. The committee agreed to wait for the return of Rains
so that all the scripts can be produced with him playing Jefferson.
Harley and Papp are experimenting with smaller musical organizations for
future shows. The first show cost about $5,200.00. With a 16-piece orchestra,
subsequent shows have cost $4,200.00. At this price, there is about enough
money left to produce six more shows. These costs are for writing, acting,
and production. They do nob include administration. Harley and Papp are ex¬
perimenting also with reduced casts on future shows. (Harley thought it might
be possible to use money from the Iron and Steel. Institute to pay for two or
three more shows—more on this later.)
Siegel said that he thought that thirteen shows were a must. Harley said they
were trying to get them, but that he didn’t want to sacrifice the quality on
individual shows. Siegel thoughtthat at least he should proceed to have 13
scripts written. This was agreed to. Wheatley thought that they should try
to produce a show with no music, or with a single instrument. Harley agreed
to work on this idea.
Probst said that one of the major problems was to get Malone to process the
Jefferson scripts more rapidly. Malone, has always worked at a much more
leisurely pace and spends a great deal of time checking carefully anything he
is responsible for. Probst suggested that we should bring in Douglas Adair,
of the University of Virginia, to help Malone. It would be his job to relieve
Malone of some of the responsibility for approving plans of the scripts.
Malone has great respect for Adair’s judgment, and this would enable Malone
to feel that he has some assurance of professional concurrence in the decisions
he is making.
Siegel pointed out that we have a daily overhead of $70.00. He thought that
the wH.t1.ng should be done first, before any producers, etc., were hired.
Harley pointed out that he and Papp were the whole office staff on the Jeffer¬
son series, and further emphasized the importance of having the producer work
with the writer and others all the way through. Probst said that we were
having to go through a long educational process v&th Malone, and that we were
paying the tuition. Probst felt that there would have been no scripts if Papp
hadn’t been on the job full time. Hull said that he thought the costs were
staggering and that we certainly needed more planning in the future. Siegel
said that if advertising agencies operated the way we have, they’d be out of
business in no time. Probst reiterated that the educational process was long
and difficult and cost time and money. Siegel said that may be true, but in
• the future we should get the scripts written before hiring a producer and staff
